fr:mainmatter.html:p: We have an adjunction of functors \mathsf {CRing}^\textrm {op} \xtofrom [\Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_{(-)})]{\operatorname {Spec}} \mathsf {Sch}, with \operatorname {Spec} being the right adjoint (or \operatorname {Spec} : \mathsf {CRing} \to \mathsf {Sch}^\textrm {op} being the left adjoint). In fact, we can replace \mathsf {Sch} with the category of locally ringed spaces \mathsf {LRS}, of whom \mathsf {Sch} is a full subcategory.

We need to give a natural bijection \hom (X, \operatorname {Spec}(R)) \cong \hom (R, \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X)). In other words, maps X \to \operatorname {Spec}(R) between locally ringed spaces are uniquely specified by the action of global sections.

Since X is glued from affine open subschemes, a map from X is equivalent to a map from each open subscheme \operatorname {Spec}(S_i) that agree on common restrictions (which again can be checked on an affine covering). Since the codomain is affine, these maps are equivalently ring homomorphisms R \to S_i by Theorem . The elements of \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X) are also given by a set of compatible elements from S_i. Hence these two sets are naturally bijective.

Given a scheme S, we can produce a best affine approximation S \to S' for it. This serves as the adjoint unit of the adjunction of global section and \operatorname {Spec}. Here we give a construction from the ground up.

We define S' = \operatorname {Spec} \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X). For the map S \to S', we define the preimage of the distinguished open D(f) to be the non-vanishing open of f \in \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X), which is defined on each affine subscheme as the distinguished open of f. This is obviously continuous. We can then pull back a section f/g by considering them as an element of \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X) and restricting them.
A scheme is affine iff the affinification is an isomorphism. This is a formal consequence that affine schemes form a full subcategory of schemes.

Morphism of affine schemes are in natural bijection with ring homomorphisms in the opposite direction. In other words, there is a fully faithful embedding \mathsf {CRing}^\textrm {op} \to \mathsf {Sch}.

Given two rings R, S, a ring homomorphism \varphi : S \to R naturally induces a map of distinguished opens f \mapsto \varphi (f). This is a continuous map \operatorname {Spec}(R) \to \operatorname {Spec}(S), because \varphi preserves \operatorname {lcm} and \gcd on radical ideals. For the structure sheaf, we can use the distinguished basis, thus we need to supply a ring homomorphism \Gamma (D(s), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(S)}) \to \Gamma (D(r), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(R)}) whenever D(r) \subseteq \varphi ^{-1}D(s) = D(\varphi (s)). This is just a homomorphism S[s^{-1}] \to R[r^{-1}], which is obvious because \varphi (s) must be invertible in R[r^{-1}].

We need to prove our map is local. Using the characterization on stalks, we just need to verify that S_{\varphi ^{-1}(\mathfrak {p})} \to R_{\mathfrak {p}} reflects invertibility. This is true by construction. Hence we have a map \hom _{\mathsf {CRing}}(S, R) \to \hom _{\mathsf {Sch}}(\operatorname {Spec}(R), \operatorname {Spec}(S)).
Given a ringed space, i.e. a space X with a sheaf of rings \mathscr {O}, it is said to be locally ringed iff the following conditions hold.

html:ul.html:li: Suppose f + g \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}) is invertible, then we can cover U with two open sets such that f and g are invertible when restricted respectively.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This can be unified as one condition: If a finite sum in \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}) is invertible, then each summand is invertible when restricted to an open, which jointly covers U.
